Dad's Army Marches On

While support for the classic drama, Dad's Army, has by no means diminished in recent years, the fan-base has undoubtedly got older

RCS' Jamie Luck lets Nouse into the secret of Shakespeare's unremitting success

There are statues, memorials and theatre companies dedicated to him worldwide, and throngs of camera-wielding tourists descend on his birthplace daily, but how is it that sixteenth century playwright William Shakespeare remains so popular after all these centuries? (Thumbnail credit Jamie Luck with school children, copyright: RSC)

Terrorism

I'm sure I was not the only one looking forward to watching the Young Actors Company's latest instalment at the Theatre Royal; it follows the success of <em>Equus</em> back in October, and worked off another weighty script of potent socio-political relevance

It is not often that a film's trailer underrepresents rather than overrepresents the dramatic force of the film itself

Three Sisters

As Chekhov's Three Sisters begins, the audience finds themselves present at the anniversary of someone's death (Thumbnail credit Photo: Mike Oakes)

I Love You Phillip Morris

Jim Carrey has continued the tendency which began with <em>The Truman Show</em> to surprise his critics every couple of years

Adolf Hitler: My Part in His Downfall

If World War II comedy performed by a jazz quartet is your sort of thing, you might be on to a winner with Spike Milligan's <em>Adolf Hitler: My Part in His Downfall</em>. If, as I expect is true of many of you, you have never considered the advantages of this style of theatre, you are certainly in for a pleasant surprise
